title: Episode 22 â€“ Sahar Alsahlani on InterFaith & GreenFaith Action
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.8s - 16.2s]: Hi friends, welcome to today's edition of the Wyon Earth Communities Stewardship and

[16.2s - 18.2s]: Sustainability Podcast Series.

[18.6s - 24.6s]: And today I'm so excited that we have with us, Sahar, Al Salani, Hi Sahar.

[26.2s - 27.4s]: It's so great to see you.

[27.8s - 29.6s]: Thank you so much for having me.

[29.6s - 30.4s]: Thank you, Aaron.

[31.0s - 32.2s]: Thank you for being with us.

[33.5s - 39.7s]: Sahar is an interfaith peace activist with a background in broadcast media and entertainment.

[40.6s - 48.3s]: Most recently determined to pursue a path for social good, the Iraq-born Muslim made a life-changing

[48.3s - 54.3s]: decision to move to New York and leave behind a successful career in Los Angeles, where

[54.3s - 58.3s]: she had worked for many years as a television writer, producer, and editor.

[59.1s - 65.8s]: Sahar's various projects included productions for USA Broadcasting, Warner Brothers, Entertainment,

[66.2s - 71.0s]: Fox, Paramount, the American Forces Network, and Discovery ID.

[72.7s - 78.2s]: Now along with serving on the board of the North American Interfaith Network, Sahar is

[78.2s - 82.8s]: a member of the Executive Council of Religions for Peace, USA.

[83.7s - 90.2s]: The board of Council on American Islamic Relations in New York has contributed to the faith-based

[90.2s - 96.7s]: outreach of the revived Poor People's Campaign, a national call for moral revival, and is

[96.7s - 102.2s]: a fellow at Green Faith and Interfaith Organization dedicated to climate justice.

[103.2s - 109.5s]: Sahar has also served as a former co-chair of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, USA.

[110.2s - 115.3s]: She is a member of the Community of Living Traditions at the Stony Point Center just outside

[115.3s - 121.7s]: New York City, one of North America's only intentional multi-faith communities intended

[121.7s - 128.0s]: for studying the principles and practice of social justice, non-violence, and radical

[128.0s - 132.3s]: hospitality. Sahar, it is such a pleasure to have you with us today.

[132.6s - 133.5s]: Welcome, my friend.

[134.5s - 135.3s]: Thank you.

[135.5s - 136.9s]: Thank you so much.

[137.0s - 138.8s]: That's always really good to see you, Erin.

[139.8s - 141.3s]: So, hello to everybody out there.

[142.1s - 142.7s]: Hi, everybody.

[143.3s - 151.3s]: We met a number of months ago at an Interfaith Climate Summit that was being hosted in Colorado.

[151.3s - 157.1s]: And we today have so much we can talk about and share with folks.

[157.7s - 164.6s]: And really at this nexus of concern for environment, for social justice in communities all over,

[164.9s - 173.5s]: and how that relates and connects to our diverse faith practices is such a rich groundwork

[173.5s - 175.9s]: for discussion exploration for sharing.

[175.9s - 180.9s]: And Sahar, I want to ask you to kick us off.

[181.0s - 185.2s]: What is an Interfaith Peace activist?

[185.4s - 186.2s]: What does that mean?

[187.7s - 194.6s]: Well, anybody that follows any path of moral conscience, whether it's following a particular

[195.3s - 204.6s]: code of laws, a democracy, a socialist ideal, a path to a divine, is really a roadmap to

[204.6s - 205.0s]: justice.

[205.6s - 213.3s]: Anyone of our holy scriptures is really a set of guidelines to conduct ourselves in a life

[213.3s - 218.5s]: that is geared towards equity and balance for ourselves and for those around us.

[219.4s - 224.9s]: And so when you are an activist and you're searching for justice and you're searching for

[224.9s - 229.0s]: balance, it has to come from something inherent within you.

[229.4s - 234.0s]: And a lot of times it is from a path that guides you towards a path in a divine.

[234.0s - 239.1s]: It doesn't necessarily have to be, but there is something inherently that drives you to

[239.1s - 239.6s]: do good.

[240.3s - 246.4s]: And when you pursue that path and you have your conviction to work for justice, it can

[246.4s - 249.1s]: only be amplified when it's done collectively.

[249.5s - 253.4s]: Because then exponentially the results can only be spectacular.

[254.1s - 259.7s]: And I think that's the movement that's really had to happen in the last few decades in

[259.7s - 264.9s]: this country because so many people have been fighting for the same things, but have been

[264.9s - 266.2s]: doing it in parallel tracks.

[266.9s - 272.7s]: And only recently with this spread of television and radio at the mass level and now with the

[272.7s - 277.2s]: internet, do we really see, oh wow, this group is actually asking for the same thing we're

[277.2s - 277.4s]: doing.

[277.8s - 282.9s]: And they actually have advocacy organizations and they have lobbying and they do feed the

[282.9s - 286.7s]: homeless and they do have jets that are ready to go and disperse at a moment's notice.

[287.3s - 293.9s]: And that is really the power of what the moral conscious movement could do to act to mobilize

[293.9s - 297.3s]: the political climate, I think in this country and abroad.

[297.8s - 304.4s]: Yeah, I was so struck when we first met and in the subsequent conversations and exchanges

[304.4s - 311.9s]: that we've had that you clearly come from, act from your heart and a sense of love, of

[312.1s - 313.3s]: compassion, of empathy.

[314.2s - 319.6s]: And it seems to me that's one of the keys to creating the culture in the future.

[319.6s - 321.4s]: I think we all hope for it.

[321.8s - 323.8s]: And I'm curious, share with us if you would.

[324.6s - 325.7s]: How do you do that?

[325.8s - 327.0s]: How do you cultivate that?

[327.2s - 331.0s]: How do you come from heart like you do day in and day out?

[332.4s - 333.2s]: Thank you.

[333.4s - 333.7s]: Thank you.

[333.8s - 335.4s]: Well, it's not easy.

[335.4s - 338.5s]: I think it's kind of twofold.

[339.0s - 346.6s]: I think in any kind of moral tradition, there's always a dichotomy, if you will.

[347.1s - 354.4s]: Several traditions feel that the concept of divine stems from an emotional love aspect.

[354.9s - 358.5s]: And there are other traditions that stem from a rational aspect.

[359.7s - 362.4s]: I know that Islam has 99 names of the divine.

[362.8s - 363.9s]: One of them is love.

[364.4s - 366.0s]: One of them is justice.

[366.2s - 367.0s]: One of them is truth.

[367.3s - 368.2s]: One of them is reckoning.

[368.8s - 375.4s]: So the concept of God is so up here that nobody really knows what the tangible concept

[375.4s - 375.8s]: is.

[376.2s - 380.4s]: So a lot of times I have met people that are claimed to be atheists and, oh, what is this

[380.4s - 381.8s]: concept of love?

[382.0s - 383.6s]: And I'm like, well, it's also justice.

[383.9s - 384.7s]: You know, it's also truth.

[385.0s - 385.9s]: It's also harmony.

[386.1s - 387.1s]: It's also accountability.

[387.9s - 393.4s]: And so I happened to come from the Islamic tradition, but I grew up in Catholic schools.

[393.4s - 396.3s]: And I also went to a lot of Jewish summer camps.

[396.7s - 404.0s]: So I've noticed that from the Islamic perspective, the first word that was revealed from the

[404.0s - 409.5s]: angel Gabriel to the prophet Muhammad was the word, ecrac, an Arabic, ecrac, which means

[409.5s - 412.2s]: to read, analyze, debate, argue, think.

[412.9s - 418.7s]: So before God instructs the prophet Muhammad to believe in God blindly, he instructs him to

[418.7s - 423.7s]: use the rational part and to seek for truth and to seek for knowledge and to understand

[423.7s - 427.7s]: how the parts lead to understanding the concept of the divine.

[428.1s - 432.3s]: And in Catholic school, I really learned the other portion of understanding the emotional

[432.3s - 435.7s]: part of it, you know, the love unconditionally.

[436.2s - 439.5s]: You know, and you kind of eat both in life, you know, which is kind of amazing because

[439.5s - 446.3s]: the concept of God, the divine is really, you know, to be spiritually holy, you have to understand

[446.3s - 447.6s]: any have to feel, you know.

[448.2s - 453.3s]: And I think that's kind of where I cultivated from is to really understand what the fight

[453.3s - 457.8s]: for justice is and then to feel in the heart what is right and wrong.

[458.2s - 460.0s]: So I think that's where it came from.

[460.9s - 462.5s]: And I don't know a lot of therapy too.

[462.9s - 468.8s]: And just like, you know, raising my children and I think understanding, you know, that

[468.8s - 477.6s]: it takes a lot of personal growth, a lot of personal growth with struggles and life.

[477.9s - 482.2s]: And you learn a lot and you see things in your perspective changes, I think, in life.

[483.1s - 483.7s]: Absolutely.

[485.2s - 492.2s]: This is one of the themes that we speak about in Y on earth and through the Y on earth

[492.2s - 500.3s]: communities work this notion that that personal healing and development and quest really on

[500.3s - 507.5s]: some level is so essential and that really on in a certain light, this whole sustainability

[508.5s - 511.5s]: effort and work is an inside out job.

[511.5s - 517.4s]: And it seems to me that you really have embodied that and exemplify that in a beautiful way.

[517.7s - 521.5s]: And in the communities all over that you're reaching and that you're working with.

[522.2s - 526.6s]: Well, thank you. Thank you. Well, you know, and there's there's the concept that every

[526.6s - 531.8s]: tradition has. I know personally in Islam, we call it the jihad, which is the struggle for a

[531.8s - 538.8s]: personal vest. And I know one of my favorite quotes from the prophet Laouzou from the Taoist

[538.8s - 546.3s]: tradition is to know to know others is knowledge, I believe, but to know one's self is enlightenment.

[547.0s - 553.3s]: And you know, a struggle for justice and truth in the outside world is a larger jihad,

[553.6s - 558.0s]: you know, is a large jihad, but the knowledge of oneself and finding that balance and

[558.0s - 564.3s]: harbingion, liberating any internalized oppression in here is really actually the greater jihad,

[564.5s - 569.4s]: the internal one, because if you don't have any, if you don't fight for justice for your own soul

[569.4s - 575.1s]: and calmness and tranquility and fight the inner demons, there's no way that I can ever even

[575.1s - 581.2s]: talk to you about fighting for trees or fighting for clean water if I don't have this all in sync.

[581.7s - 587.5s]: So it really does begin in here. And I think a lot of activists, we need to forget about this part,

[587.9s - 592.1s]: you know, and when you're on an airplane, who did they tell to put the oxygen mask on first?

[592.7s - 596.9s]: Now, you know, if you don't, then everybody else around you was like, we're not in your room.

[597.6s - 602.8s]: So the important thing is really, really to work on it simultaneously, but it's better to work on

[602.8s - 604.7s]: this first, the internal.

[605.4s - 612.1s]: What I'd like you, I'd like to ask you if you would to expand a little on this term jihad,

[612.4s - 619.4s]: you know, it's one that I have found many of my friends, colleagues, family in the United States,

[619.9s - 626.1s]: have a very particular, and I would even say negative standing of what that word means because

[626.1s - 632.8s]: of the way it's been used in popular media, etc. And what you're speaking to is a very different

[633.3s - 638.7s]: meaning about self-cultivation, self-awareness. And I'm hoping, would you expand on that for us?

[638.8s - 645.5s]: I would love for for our friends and audience to have a deeper and broader understanding of what that means.

[646.6s - 652.9s]: Sure, sure. Well, thank you. The term jihad actually is such a holy thing,

[653.1s - 658.4s]: it's such a holy precious concept. It's actually, it's actually a personal, as I said,

[658.4s - 665.9s]: struggle, but it is a quest towards the divine, a path that is never an easy path.

[666.7s - 675.9s]: And if the divine encompasses the various attributes that go into the various nuances of what

[675.9s - 682.8s]: the divine means to so many people, it never is an easy road. So if we do want to find justice

[682.8s - 690.7s]: or righteousness or all these things for for every living thing on this planet, we don't have a

[690.7s - 696.7s]: magic wand, you know, and that takes effort and that takes enlightenment and that takes energy

[696.7s - 703.0s]: and that takes partnerships and companionships and communication skills and, you know,

[703.5s - 708.9s]: management and organizational skills. And that's really what it means. It means a struggle to do

[708.9s - 717.0s]: any job you do in the best way with the using the resources that you have and learning how to use

[717.0s - 723.4s]: those resources in the most efficient way. And the energy how does also this evening, what are the

[723.4s - 733.0s]: best techniques you have to make the best use of your emotions and your insight and your attitude.

[733.0s - 738.9s]: And yes, it has been hijacked. It really has been hijacked. I know that the term became synonymous

[738.9s - 746.3s]: with a holy war or crusade during the time of the crusades in Europe. So it became adopted around

[746.3s - 754.2s]: that same time. And it is sadly not the first time another holy word has been hijacked. I fear now

[754.2s - 760.2s]: for a lot of my friends who are evangelical. And I'm the first person, I've been to a couple,

[760.2s - 765.7s]: a couple inner faith gatherings. I mean, even when I did my work on the poor people's campaign,

[766.2s - 770.8s]: I remember telling a lot of my evangelical friends or even Christian friends since one is spreading

[770.8s - 776.8s]: the gospel, ever been a bad thing. And now a lot of people, you know, have sort of misused the word

[776.8s - 784.1s]: to evangelize. And it is really tragic when people take words and associate them with different

[784.1s - 791.5s]: political efforts or different, you know, right wing or left wing. So thank you very much for asking

[791.5s - 798.7s]: me that question. But it is a personal struggle to do your very best on your journey towards the path,

[798.9s - 809.4s]: towards the divine. Beautiful. Well, you know, as a writer and I will also share as a student of

[809.4s - 818.1s]: Catholic schools, I went to a Jesuit high school, I have a total word nerd. I love the history behind

[818.1s - 825.5s]: words, the etymology of words. And it seems to me that part of the work we're doing also involves

[826.2s - 833.6s]: reclaiming what certain words mean and sharing and conversing and and and celebrating more like a

[833.6s - 841.4s]: feast in the richness that some of these words and the traditions that they reflect can mean to us.

[842.0s - 848.4s]: And so thank you so much for sharing that. It's wonderful to hear that the quest toward the

[848.4s - 858.9s]: divine, what a beautiful, beautiful concept and urge and impulse. Thank you. Well, so your background

[858.9s - 865.4s]: is so interesting. It makes me think of a garden with many colored flowers which remind me of this

[865.4s - 872.1s]: painting behind me. And you know, you live outside New York City just north along the Hudson River,

[872.1s - 879.6s]: just a beautiful part of the North American continent. You were in LA for a while working in

[879.6s - 889.9s]: one of the global centers of media culture. And you are from Iraq and from you told me earlier one

[889.9s - 897.3s]: of the oldest indigenous groups on the planet known to be on the planet. And my goodness, what a

[897.3s - 903.2s]: what a rich background and story and experience. And I was wondering if you could just share with us

[903.2s - 916.1s]: a montage, an image, an impressionistic view into what your childhood was like and what is there in

[916.1s - 919.5s]: your early experiences that you're carrying with you today.

[921.0s - 929.5s]: Oh, gee, thank you. Gosh, well, my mom and my dad are both Iraqi born. I was born in Saudi Arabia.

[929.5s - 937.1s]: I came when I was a month old. My mom, she got a student visa. She completed her PhD here. So I

[937.1s - 944.0s]: was about a month old when we came. I settled in Pittsburgh and I grew up in a very pluralistic,

[944.3s - 950.7s]: you know, Pittsburgh was a very, very intellectually sophisticated town. And actually the synagogue,

[951.5s - 957.1s]: tragically, the synagogue that was attacked not too long ago, I spent a large part of my childhood

[957.1s - 963.1s]: there because honestly, we didn't know who was who in Pittsburgh. You know, we had Hindu professors

[963.1s - 969.2s]: and we had Vietnamese immigrants coming in and we had synagogues and we actually do have a mosque

[969.2s - 975.1s]: so we used to go to the Syrian Orthodox Church. And so they would give us the keys for Friday prayer

[975.1s - 983.1s]: and I used to do JCC summer camps. So I grew up in a very multi-layered, you know, pluralistic town.

[983.1s - 988.4s]: Jewish community that are JCC? Yeah, Jewish community centers. Yes, at the tree, you know,

[988.6s - 995.6s]: which was adjacent to the tree of life synagogue that was tragically attacked last month.

[996.2s - 1001.5s]: And you know, actually I went to about 11 botmits was there, you know, as a child. And so

[1001.5s - 1006.7s]: those were really our houses of worship. Mr. Rogers lived about six blocks away from me and so,

[1006.9s - 1012.6s]: you know, a Presbyterian mentality from the early ages. He taught us about social justice. He

[1012.6s - 1017.3s]: taught us to share our cookies. He taught us to like, you know, have equal even the neighborhood

[1017.3s - 1022.6s]: of make believe. We used to go to the set of Mr. Rogers and the animals and the people

[1022.6s - 1026.9s]: how had equal power in the neighborhood of make believe. Like in the 70s, everything was such a

[1026.9s - 1032.2s]: social justice subtly infused, you know, area that we just never even noticed. Everything was

[1032.2s - 1038.5s]: anti-war, everything was vegan. I mean, so early in the 70s. And so I finished elementary,

[1038.5s - 1044.3s]: middle high school. I finished high school in college in Florida, I had my children. And then

[1044.3s - 1050.5s]: I ended up taking my children. I raised my children in Los Angeles and I worked there. I got a

[1050.5s - 1055.0s]: degree in public health. After my children were younger, I went back to school for television.

[1055.7s - 1062.5s]: And I ended up working in Los Angeles for about 13 years. It raised them there. I worked in

[1062.5s - 1068.7s]: the television industry. And then I was actually an empty master. And a dear friend of ours,

[1068.9s - 1074.0s]: Ravelin Gottlieb, my children grew up in Islamic schools. I grew up in Catholic schools. So I

[1074.0s - 1079.0s]: wanted them to do pro-kale schools. So Ravelin Gottlieb used to do these interfaith summer camps

[1079.0s - 1083.7s]: for children. So actually, my kids were like, Mom, you got to get a life. You're by yourself now.

[1083.7s - 1088.1s]: We're out in Korn College. Ravelin said, why don't you come? We're doing this experiment

[1088.8s - 1093.8s]: just outside New York City where we're getting together a bunch of Muslim Jews and Christians.

[1093.8s - 1097.3s]: We're going to run a conference center and we're going to try this interfaith peace building

[1098.2s - 1103.5s]: concept. And so the rest is history. I just packed up and moved out here. And I've just the first

[1103.5s - 1111.2s]: two years. I just really had to learn how to live on a farm. I'm from LA, remember. And I had

[1111.2s - 1116.1s]: to really study the different traditions including my own and just learned the verb age because it's

[1116.1s - 1120.6s]: a whole different game than television. I mean, I had to learn the words like movement building.

[1120.9s - 1126.5s]: And you know, just what is bearing witness mean and what is feco-justice because it's such a

[1126.5s - 1133.7s]: whole different world than what most mainstream people talk about, which is a shame. But it's

[1133.7s - 1142.1s]: finna blessing. It sounds so wonderful and so beautiful. Will you share with us some of the

[1142.1s - 1148.0s]: specifics that you're working on through these organizations like Green Faith where you're a

[1148.0s - 1152.4s]: fellow. Let's maybe start with that one. I know there are several we can talk about. Can you

[1152.4s - 1158.2s]: share with us some of the the specific actions that are being mobilized in communities all over

[1158.2s - 1164.3s]: through that organization? Yes, yes. I think Green Faith actually is probably

[1165.7s - 1171.0s]: most precious organization to me. The organization that I have learned the most from.

[1171.6s - 1176.6s]: Because I had, you know, everybody always talks about wanting to be an environmentalist.

[1177.1s - 1182.7s]: You know, and as when we're children, we learn about recycling and we learn about so many little

[1182.7s - 1189.1s]: things about being, you know, green peace and a lot of things. But it wasn't until I started working

[1189.1s - 1198.1s]: on their climate march a couple of years ago as a volunteer that I really understood what the

[1198.1s - 1207.7s]: intersection was between faith, moral conscious and ecology. And as I told you, my my

[1207.7s - 1211.8s]: masters was in public health. My undergraduate was in geography. So there's always a little bit of

[1211.8s - 1218.4s]: excitement about the environment and the earth. But never did I once ever think that my Islam had

[1218.4s - 1225.6s]: anything to do with the earth. You know, even though hello, we come from dust. We shall return to

[1225.6s - 1229.7s]: dust. I mean, our symbol is the crescent. You know, like, we just never put these two and two

[1229.7s - 1237.6s]: things together. But it wasn't until I learned from Green Faith and helping to organize all these

[1237.6s - 1245.4s]: faith communities. We call ourselves A to Z years agnostic to Zora Astrian. And why it was imperative

[1245.4s - 1252.4s]: in all of our faith traditions to mobilize from other earth. Did it hit me that it was such an important

[1252.4s - 1258.1s]: part? I discovered books that were like this thick and every faith tradition when I was recruiting

[1258.1s - 1263.4s]: Baha'is, when I was recruiting the druids, when I was recruiting, you know, the Buddhist,

[1263.6s - 1270.0s]: when I was recruiting the Hindus, I found ecogestus in the Sikh community. And every single scripture

[1270.6s - 1276.5s]: resonates with the earth and all talks about the concept of us being stewards with the earth.

[1276.8s - 1281.1s]: You know, for the earth and how we're supposed to walk gently on the earth and how we are not

[1281.1s - 1285.2s]: dominant with regards to the earth, how we are made, you know, part of the big ecological

[1285.2s - 1291.6s]: live and how it wasn't a imperative, like a moral imperative, to respect the mother earth.

[1292.2s - 1298.1s]: And how ultimately we are held accountable on the day of judgment for our ego and how much we

[1298.1s - 1305.4s]: misuse the resources. And then Lodato Si came right around 2015, the Pope's, you know, on a Catholic

[1305.4s - 1313.2s]: school kid. So when the Pope wrote the book, his Lodato Si, the Pope also has a master's degree

[1313.2s - 1320.2s]: in science. So it was wonderful to show people that science and religion don't clash, but there

[1320.2s - 1325.9s]: is that intellectual sophistication and the moral part that really does drive, you know, that,

[1326.3s - 1332.7s]: you know, reason and, you know, reason and faith really do come together and how we are held

[1332.7s - 1339.1s]: accountable to how we misuse resources because of our greed and ego and how we'll be held morally

[1339.1s - 1345.7s]: accountable to that. And what, what, since we are, you know, what, since we are committing by

[1345.7s - 1351.8s]: violating mother earth and what, what ramifications we have to other creatures on this earth, I think

[1351.8s - 1356.8s]: that's probably what I learned most from Greenfield and the projects that they do are phenomenal

[1356.8s - 1362.5s]: because they really are geared towards houses of worship. So for example, we're trying to start from

[1362.5s - 1367.2s]: the top, like they're trying to green the Vatican, they're trying to green Mekka, you know, like

[1367.2s - 1372.3s]: every house of worship now, they're trying to tell them, if you're going to do Ramadan, don't use

[1372.3s - 1377.3s]: plastic, you know, don't, you don't use paper cups, recycle your woo-hoo water, every church,

[1377.6s - 1382.8s]: every Sikh goodwara, every Hindi temple, you know, use, you know, fresh fruits and vegetables from

[1382.8s - 1389.3s]: your local farmer, you know, teach your children at an early age, you know, that the earth is holy,

[1389.3s - 1396.0s]: make sure that, you know, you divest, you know, a lot of the major denominations are divesting from

[1396.0s - 1401.0s]: fossil fuels because, you know, the end of the day houses of worship have money, they have voter

[1401.0s - 1407.0s]: registration hubs, you know, they do do major purchases. I mean every Christmas party, every

[1407.0s - 1413.1s]: Eid festival, every church social, you know, and it's all conscience living inside the lowest

[1413.1s - 1417.6s]: points, like your local house, like local hubs, not the lowest, but your most tangible house,

[1417.6s - 1422.5s]: and at the hierarchist, you know, Skit, you know, part also. So that's really what a green

[1422.5s - 1431.1s]: faith has been working on. So beautiful, so powerful, so, so humble yet so far reaching in its

[1431.1s - 1437.6s]: scope of impact in my sense with some of the different green faith leaders and projects I've been

[1437.6s - 1443.7s]: able to tap into just a little that things are just really getting rolling and the momentum is

[1443.7s - 1449.4s]: building and it seems that more and more is getting activated in communities all over. It's amazing.

[1449.8s - 1455.3s]: Yes, yes, I mean it really, really has been like a chain reaction. And even when Lodato

[1455.3s - 1462.4s]: C was published, it became mandatory reading for a lot of youth groups, I mean a lot of mosques,

[1462.6s - 1467.8s]: a lot of synagogues, a lot of Sikh and Hindu temples, and a lot of pagan like mother grows.

[1468.4s - 1473.3s]: I mean that was mandatory reading for clergy and then abbreviated versions for the youth groups

[1473.3s - 1479.3s]: and for the children to talk about the concept of our common home. And what moral sins we were

[1481.1s - 1486.6s]: perpetrating because of our greed and how we just kept digging into mother earth and abusing her.

[1487.2s - 1491.9s]: And one of my favorite sayings that we taught the kids is there is no planet B like where are we going to go?

[1492.6s - 1498.6s]: You know, we can't go anywhere. And to show them that the correlation between today's migration

[1499.2s - 1506.2s]: is really very directly related to climate change. And you know almost almost every, I was at the

[1506.2s - 1512.4s]: parliament and I heard from one of the speakers that almost every single humanitarian crisis can

[1512.4s - 1518.6s]: be somehow traced back to violation of the earth. You know, I mean when a hurricane hits or when

[1518.6s - 1524.7s]: a flood hits, that leads to migration, sex trafficking, kids pulled out of school, systematic violence,

[1524.7s - 1531.5s]: racism. I mean you name it. It just goes on epidemics, epidemial logically infections happen and

[1531.5s - 1538.7s]: and water sanitation and it just goes on and on and on. And it all starts with how morally we handle

[1538.7s - 1542.0s]: God's resources and how we distribute them equitably.

[1543.0s - 1549.8s]: Oh it's yeah it's it's amazing. Let me while I'm thinking of it, let me just take a quick pause

[1549.8s - 1557.4s]: in our conversation to Sharon remind with our audience that this is the why on earth communities

[1557.4s - 1564.3s]: stewardship and sustainability podcast series. And today we are talking with Sahar Al Salani,

[1564.9s - 1574.6s]: an incredible faith leader activist and ecologist social justice leader based out of the

[1574.6s - 1581.2s]: New York area. And I want to make sure to mention if anyone would like to learn more about

[1581.2s - 1588.3s]: your work Sahar, they can find you on Facebook, Sahar, also Lonnie of course that'll be spelled out

[1588.3s - 1596.4s]: in the show notes. And on Twitter can find you as Iraqi sunflower. We'll come back to that in

[1596.4s - 1602.0s]: just a moment. And I want to make sure also to remind our audience if you would like to

[1602.0s - 1609.3s]: get any of the audiobook or ebook resources that we have available through why on earth. That's

[1609.3s - 1617.9s]: why on earth.org letter why. Please use the code podcast, the word podcast to get a discount on any

[1617.9s - 1624.9s]: of those that you might like. And so Sahar, I have to ask where did you come up with your Twitter

[1624.9s - 1632.9s]: handle? I love it. So sorry, you know, actually my kids actually came up with it probably about 20

[1632.9s - 1637.6s]: years ago. And you know, they actually started my Twitter account and it sort of stuck. They

[1637.6s - 1643.3s]: all these young ins like you guys are so good with technology. So they started it and I hadn't

[1643.3s - 1648.4s]: realized that that was the Twitter handle they were using, you know, and it actually wasn't by accident

[1648.4s - 1653.6s]: that I sort of figured it out because I was in a podcast sort of similar to this. And there was

[1653.6s - 1658.6s]: there was this gentleman next to me who was a little bit larger with this big beard and our Twitter

[1658.6s - 1664.9s]: handles got switched. So I had his name and he had adi rakhi sunflower. So it's just kind of cute how it

[1664.9s - 1672.8s]: happened. But that's the story. Wow. Oh my gosh. Well, it is just beautiful. So yeah, folks can find

[1672.8s - 1680.7s]: you and I understand that early in 2019, you may be launching a new project with a new website

[1680.7s - 1686.2s]: that will be announced probably through Twitter and Facebook. Is that right? Is that how folks can

[1686.2s - 1693.0s]: keep up with with what you're doing? Yes, yes. Inshallah. I hope to God willing. I've been working on it

[1693.0s - 1700.7s]: and I've been looking for the best way to combine my my television experience with my passion of

[1700.7s - 1706.3s]: interfaith peace activism. So keep keep checking in and hopefully within the next six weeks something

[1706.3s - 1713.1s]: will something will appear and we'll definitely keep you posted. Beautiful. You know, I'd loved it.

[1713.3s - 1720.6s]: I'd love to ask you what's happening with the efforts of organizations like the board of the

[1720.6s - 1728.7s]: council on American Islamic relations and I I understand you're likely starting a new position on

[1728.7s - 1734.5s]: the board of the North American interfaith network. And you know, there has been so much

[1735.6s - 1744.3s]: energy of divisiveness of polarization evident in the media and there's probably a lot of fear

[1744.3s - 1752.4s]: out there among different groups. Of course, one of the great works we can do inside ourselves is to

[1753.1s - 1760.2s]: work to transform that fear into love into work in our communities to transform conditions for fear

[1760.2s - 1767.3s]: to conditions for safety and acceptance. And clearly, there's so much work to be done in the

[1767.3s - 1773.2s]: Serena. And can you share with us some of the things these groups are doing right now and ways

[1773.2s - 1781.3s]: people can get involved and help with this healing work? Yes, thank you. You know, a lot of these

[1781.3s - 1787.7s]: advocacy organizations are all really they're all doing the same work and they're doing amazing

[1787.7s - 1794.1s]: work, but it's parallel. It's a lot of people as I said earlier do not know what others are doing.

[1794.4s - 1800.2s]: That became evident when I was working in green faith. You know, we didn't realize that the Buddhist

[1800.2s - 1805.9s]: global relief was doing something very similar to what the Mormons were doing. Pagans are doing

[1805.9s - 1811.7s]: very similar work and sending things to Puerto Rico when the Hindus and the Amish are working together

[1811.7s - 1817.6s]: to send jets there every week. And so there's this huge amount of faith-based activism that is

[1818.6s - 1824.4s]: happening simultaneously. But there was just very little communication, not intentionally. It

[1824.4s - 1832.0s]: says that people are so focused on their own work and their little hubs. So a lot of the opportunities

[1832.6s - 1836.5s]: that a lot of these organizations like Religious for Peace or North American and your

[1836.5s - 1843.4s]: Faith Network is basically sort of a resource to say, hey, you know, we are doing the same thing and

[1843.8s - 1849.1s]: we don't want to duplicate efforts, but we could help simplify your efforts if you want. You know,

[1849.2s - 1854.9s]: if you have, for example, you know, like some of the Hindu temples, we have a lot of food. We have

[1854.9s - 1859.4s]: a lot of medical resources. And then the Brutorhof first can come and say, hey, well, we have four jets,

[1859.4s - 1865.6s]: you know, and so it just shows that how the resources can complement each other immediately.

[1866.3s - 1871.8s]: But another major, major, important portion is that we really showed, and I know this is like

[1871.8s - 1877.7s]: the latest buzzword, but intersectionality. And it's really when layers of oppression overlap.

[1878.4s - 1884.3s]: Because a lot of times we never realize where these layers do overlap. I mean, and I think if there's

[1884.3s - 1892.0s]: anything that has come up from the divisiveness of the last two years, it is the unlikely alliances

[1892.0s - 1898.2s]: that I have seen. I mean, you know, and I think that has what scared a lot of people, but has also

[1898.2s - 1904.6s]: been really part, possibly the most beautiful outcome of a lot of this, a lot of these tragedies,

[1905.0s - 1912.8s]: is that a lot of people understand that they are fighting for the same thing. Everybody wants

[1912.8s - 1918.3s]: a safe place for their children to put their head on a pillow and sleep. Nobody wants to be

[1918.3s - 1924.6s]: discriminated against because of who they are. You know, even if people don't agree with what they

[1924.6s - 1931.3s]: are doing, everybody agrees that they should be treated fairly under the law. And a lot of these

[1931.3s - 1938.6s]: organizations are standing up for each other in times of need. When sometimes you don't even have

[1938.6s - 1944.9s]: the energy to fight anymore. And I think that has really, really proven itself.

[1945.9s - 1952.8s]: Care, Council on American Islamic Relations, was modeled off of the NAACP. The NAACP, you know,

[1953.0s - 1958.5s]: glad was modeled, you know, Gay and lesbian was modeled off of the NAACP. But what's happened here

[1958.5s - 1965.6s]: now is we've seen how tragedies affect us. For example, if somebody in New York City gets pulled

[1965.6s - 1971.9s]: over and he's a young person who's African-American, his chances are getting pulled over or more

[1971.9s - 1980.2s]: likely and getting harassed. If that young person happens to be Latino and African-American,

[1980.6s - 1986.6s]: that chance rises higher. If that person is Latino, African-American and Muslim, then that person,

[1986.7s - 1991.9s]: that is tripling increases the chances. If that person is Latino, African-American, Muslim,

[1992.5s - 1998.4s]: and of an LGBTQ identity, I mean, then that increases it more. So we all have a vested interest

[1998.4s - 2005.0s]: in helping other marginalized communities because that affects us. And that's where all of our

[2005.0s - 2010.8s]: resources come together. And I've noticed that when we went to Standing Rock, I mean, every time,

[2011.5s - 2016.5s]: every time you see a group of people of faith standing up at these rapid response,

[2016.5s - 2021.0s]: and honestly, it looks like Halloween sometimes. I mean, you just get the whole spectrum. You know,

[2021.1s - 2026.6s]: you can find the rabbi. You can find the hijabbi. You can find the witch. You can finally

[2026.6s - 2031.7s]: indigenous. You can find the Sikh. And I think that's what really, really shocks people because

[2032.4s - 2037.4s]: there are a lot of allies that they did not, you know, when you see Gay Pride and you see a lot

[2037.4s - 2043.0s]: of these faith leaders or when you go, I mean, I remember the most precious example that I had was

[2043.8s - 2049.6s]: when the Muslim ban happened. And I'm pretty fierce. I mean, I've gone to Charlottesville. I stood in

[2049.6s - 2055.7s]: front of neo-Nazis with AK-47s. Okay, I mean, I've been pretty fierce. But when the Muslim ban happened,

[2056.9s - 2062.1s]: you know, the very first time I think about you're in a half a go right after the administration

[2062.1s - 2067.8s]: took over. I mean, this side of my body was numb. I mean, I curled up in the fetal position and I was

[2067.8s - 2074.3s]: crying. Like I was bawling for about four hours. I felt so helpless. But boom, all of a sudden,

[2074.4s - 2079.6s]: I started getting texts. And I started just getting texts from Standing Rock, from the Japanese

[2079.6s - 2084.5s]: in turn my camp that I had visited like two years before, from the Mexican farm workers that we

[2084.5s - 2089.6s]: had visited like six months before. You know, all these drag queens and Dallas were, you know,

[2089.6s - 2095.1s]: shutting down airports saying we love Muslims. The rabbis, I mean, people in Ferguson. And I guess

[2095.1s - 2101.1s]: for a minute, I knew how they must have felt when we showed up for them because they were taking

[2101.1s - 2108.0s]: care of it for me. And that's the real beauty of intersectional work and faith-based advocacy work

[2108.0s - 2113.6s]: because you get tired and you can fight for anybody else. But so when it really hits you,

[2114.1s - 2120.3s]: you just, it's hard to fight for yourself. And I think that's really the importance of the

[2120.3s - 2127.3s]: networking, these various organizations that I'm part of. It reminds me very much of what healthy

[2127.3s - 2134.4s]: ecosystems look like and how they work. It is a complex web work of relationships and

[2135.6s - 2141.5s]: interdependencies. And it is so beautiful to see that in the way you're connecting with all kinds

[2141.5s - 2147.9s]: of people and communities all over the place. And Sahar, my goodness, thank you so much for

[2148.6s - 2154.7s]: being with us today. And for all the work you're doing, I sincerely hope our audience will

[2154.7s - 2162.1s]: connect with you on Facebook, Sahar, Salani, on Twitter, the Iraqi sunflower, Iraqi sunflower.

[2162.5s - 2169.9s]: Know the front of it, Iraqi sunflower. And thank you so much, my friend, for all that you're doing.

[2170.4s - 2174.2s]: Oh my gosh, no, thank you. And we're very proud of you, Erin. You know, honestly,

[2174.2s - 2178.4s]: we're very, very proud of you and all the work you're doing. Thank you for giving us a platform

[2178.4s - 2184.7s]: to chat. Absolutely. Okay, my friend, take care. Bye bye. Bye bye.

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to today's edition of the Wyon Earth Communities Stewardship and
Sustainability Podcast Series.
And today I'm so excited that we have with us, Sahar, Al Salani, Hi Sahar.
It's so great to see you.
Thank you so much for having me.
Thank you, Aaron.
Thank you for being with us.
Sahar is an interfaith peace activist with a background in broadcast media and entertainment.
Most recently determined to pursue a path for social good, the Iraq-born Muslim made a life-changing
decision to move to New York and leave behind a successful career in Los Angeles, where
she had worked for many years as a television writer, producer, and editor.
Sahar's various projects included productions for USA Broadcasting, Warner Brothers, Entertainment,
Fox, Paramount, the American Forces Network, and Discovery ID.
Now along with serving on the board of the North American Interfaith Network, Sahar is
a member of the Executive Council of Religions for Peace, USA.
The board of Council on American Islamic Relations in New York has contributed to the faith-based
outreach of the revived Poor People's Campaign, a national call for moral revival, and is
a fellow at Green Faith and Interfaith Organization dedicated to climate justice.
Sahar has also served as a former co-chair of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, USA.
She is a member of the Community of Living Traditions at the Stony Point Center just outside
New York City, one of North America's only intentional multi-faith communities intended
for studying the principles and practice of social justice, non-violence, and radical
hospitality. Sahar, it is such a pleasure to have you with us today.
Welcome, my friend.
Thank you.
Thank you so much.
That's always really good to see you, Erin.
So, hello to everybody out there.
Hi, everybody.
We met a number of months ago at an Interfaith Climate Summit that was being hosted in Colorado.
And we today have so much we can talk about and share with folks.
And really at this nexus of concern for environment, for social justice in communities all over,
and how that relates and connects to our diverse faith practices is such a rich groundwork
for discussion exploration for sharing.
And Sahar, I want to ask you to kick us off.
What is an Interfaith Peace activist?
What does that mean?
Well, anybody that follows any path of moral conscience, whether it's following a particular
code of laws, a democracy, a socialist ideal, a path to a divine, is really a roadmap to
justice.
Anyone of our holy scriptures is really a set of guidelines to conduct ourselves in a life
that is geared towards equity and balance for ourselves and for those around us.
And so when you are an activist and you're searching for justice and you're searching for
balance, it has to come from something inherent within you.
And a lot of times it is from a path that guides you towards a path in a divine.
It doesn't necessarily have to be, but there is something inherently that drives you to
do good.
And when you pursue that path and you have your conviction to work for justice, it can
only be amplified when it's done collectively.
Because then exponentially the results can only be spectacular.
And I think that's the movement that's really had to happen in the last few decades in
this country because so many people have been fighting for the same things, but have been
doing it in parallel tracks.
And only recently with this spread of television and radio at the mass level and now with the
internet, do we really see, oh wow, this group is actually asking for the same thing we're
doing.
And they actually have advocacy organizations and they have lobbying and they do feed the
homeless and they do have jets that are ready to go and disperse at a moment's notice.
And that is really the power of what the moral conscious movement could do to act to mobilize
the political climate, I think in this country and abroad.
Yeah, I was so struck when we first met and in the subsequent conversations and exchanges
that we've had that you clearly come from, act from your heart and a sense of love, of
compassion, of empathy.
And it seems to me that's one of the keys to creating the culture in the future.
I think we all hope for it.
And I'm curious, share with us if you would.
How do you do that?
How do you cultivate that?
How do you come from heart like you do day in and day out?
Thank you.
Thank you.
Well, it's not easy.
I think it's kind of twofold.
I think in any kind of moral tradition, there's always a dichotomy, if you will.
Several traditions feel that the concept of divine stems from an emotional love aspect.
And there are other traditions that stem from a rational aspect.
I know that Islam has 99 names of the divine.
One of them is love.
One of them is justice.
One of them is truth.
One of them is reckoning.
So the concept of God is so up here that nobody really knows what the tangible concept
is.
So a lot of times I have met people that are claimed to be atheists and, oh, what is this
concept of love?
And I'm like, well, it's also justice.
You know, it's also truth.
It's also harmony.
It's also accountability.
And so I happened to come from the Islamic tradition, but I grew up in Catholic schools.
And I also went to a lot of Jewish summer camps.
So I've noticed that from the Islamic perspective, the first word that was revealed from the
angel Gabriel to the prophet Muhammad was the word, ecrac, an Arabic, ecrac, which means
to read, analyze, debate, argue, think.
So before God instructs the prophet Muhammad to believe in God blindly, he instructs him to
use the rational part and to seek for truth and to seek for knowledge and to understand
how the parts lead to understanding the concept of the divine.
And in Catholic school, I really learned the other portion of understanding the emotional
part of it, you know, the love unconditionally.
You know, and you kind of eat both in life, you know, which is kind of amazing because
the concept of God, the divine is really, you know, to be spiritually holy, you have to understand
any have to feel, you know.
And I think that's kind of where I cultivated from is to really understand what the fight
for justice is and then to feel in the heart what is right and wrong.
So I think that's where it came from.
And I don't know a lot of therapy too.
And just like, you know, raising my children and I think understanding, you know, that
it takes a lot of personal growth, a lot of personal growth with struggles and life.
And you learn a lot and you see things in your perspective changes, I think, in life.
Absolutely.
This is one of the themes that we speak about in Y on earth and through the Y on earth
communities work this notion that that personal healing and development and quest really on
some level is so essential and that really on in a certain light, this whole sustainability
effort and work is an inside out job.
And it seems to me that you really have embodied that and exemplify that in a beautiful way.
And in the communities all over that you're reaching and that you're working with.
Well, thank you. Thank you. Well, you know, and there's there's the concept that every
tradition has. I know personally in Islam, we call it the jihad, which is the struggle for a
personal vest. And I know one of my favorite quotes from the prophet Laouzou from the Taoist
tradition is to know to know others is knowledge, I believe, but to know one's self is enlightenment.
And you know, a struggle for justice and truth in the outside world is a larger jihad,
you know, is a large jihad, but the knowledge of oneself and finding that balance and
harbingion, liberating any internalized oppression in here is really actually the greater jihad,
the internal one, because if you don't have any, if you don't fight for justice for your own soul
and calmness and tranquility and fight the inner demons, there's no way that I can ever even
talk to you about fighting for trees or fighting for clean water if I don't have this all in sync.
So it really does begin in here. And I think a lot of activists, we need to forget about this part,
you know, and when you're on an airplane, who did they tell to put the oxygen mask on first?
Now, you know, if you don't, then everybody else around you was like, we're not in your room.
So the important thing is really, really to work on it simultaneously, but it's better to work on
this first, the internal.
What I'd like you, I'd like to ask you if you would to expand a little on this term jihad,
you know, it's one that I have found many of my friends, colleagues, family in the United States,
have a very particular, and I would even say negative standing of what that word means because
of the way it's been used in popular media, etc. And what you're speaking to is a very different
meaning about self-cultivation, self-awareness. And I'm hoping, would you expand on that for us?
I would love for for our friends and audience to have a deeper and broader understanding of what that means.
Sure, sure. Well, thank you. The term jihad actually is such a holy thing,
it's such a holy precious concept. It's actually, it's actually a personal, as I said,
struggle, but it is a quest towards the divine, a path that is never an easy path.
And if the divine encompasses the various attributes that go into the various nuances of what
the divine means to so many people, it never is an easy road. So if we do want to find justice
or righteousness or all these things for for every living thing on this planet, we don't have a
magic wand, you know, and that takes effort and that takes enlightenment and that takes energy
and that takes partnerships and companionships and communication skills and, you know,
management and organizational skills. And that's really what it means. It means a struggle to do
any job you do in the best way with the using the resources that you have and learning how to use
those resources in the most efficient way. And the energy how does also this evening, what are the
best techniques you have to make the best use of your emotions and your insight and your attitude.
And yes, it has been hijacked. It really has been hijacked. I know that the term became synonymous
with a holy war or crusade during the time of the crusades in Europe. So it became adopted around
that same time. And it is sadly not the first time another holy word has been hijacked. I fear now
for a lot of my friends who are evangelical. And I'm the first person, I've been to a couple,
a couple inner faith gatherings. I mean, even when I did my work on the poor people's campaign,
I remember telling a lot of my evangelical friends or even Christian friends since one is spreading
the gospel, ever been a bad thing. And now a lot of people, you know, have sort of misused the word
to evangelize. And it is really tragic when people take words and associate them with different
political efforts or different, you know, right wing or left wing. So thank you very much for asking
me that question. But it is a personal struggle to do your very best on your journey towards the path,
towards the divine. Beautiful. Well, you know, as a writer and I will also share as a student of
Catholic schools, I went to a Jesuit high school, I have a total word nerd. I love the history behind
words, the etymology of words. And it seems to me that part of the work we're doing also involves
reclaiming what certain words mean and sharing and conversing and and and celebrating more like a
feast in the richness that some of these words and the traditions that they reflect can mean to us.
And so thank you so much for sharing that. It's wonderful to hear that the quest toward the
divine, what a beautiful, beautiful concept and urge and impulse. Thank you. Well, so your background
is so interesting. It makes me think of a garden with many colored flowers which remind me of this
painting behind me. And you know, you live outside New York City just north along the Hudson River,
just a beautiful part of the North American continent. You were in LA for a while working in
one of the global centers of media culture. And you are from Iraq and from you told me earlier one
of the oldest indigenous groups on the planet known to be on the planet. And my goodness, what a
what a rich background and story and experience. And I was wondering if you could just share with us
a montage, an image, an impressionistic view into what your childhood was like and what is there in
your early experiences that you're carrying with you today.
Oh, gee, thank you. Gosh, well, my mom and my dad are both Iraqi born. I was born in Saudi Arabia.
I came when I was a month old. My mom, she got a student visa. She completed her PhD here. So I
was about a month old when we came. I settled in Pittsburgh and I grew up in a very pluralistic,
you know, Pittsburgh was a very, very intellectually sophisticated town. And actually the synagogue,
tragically, the synagogue that was attacked not too long ago, I spent a large part of my childhood
there because honestly, we didn't know who was who in Pittsburgh. You know, we had Hindu professors
and we had Vietnamese immigrants coming in and we had synagogues and we actually do have a mosque
so we used to go to the Syrian Orthodox Church. And so they would give us the keys for Friday prayer
and I used to do JCC summer camps. So I grew up in a very multi-layered, you know, pluralistic town.
Jewish community that are JCC? Yeah, Jewish community centers. Yes, at the tree, you know,
which was adjacent to the tree of life synagogue that was tragically attacked last month.
And you know, actually I went to about 11 botmits was there, you know, as a child. And so
those were really our houses of worship. Mr. Rogers lived about six blocks away from me and so,
you know, a Presbyterian mentality from the early ages. He taught us about social justice. He
taught us to share our cookies. He taught us to like, you know, have equal even the neighborhood
of make believe. We used to go to the set of Mr. Rogers and the animals and the people
how had equal power in the neighborhood of make believe. Like in the 70s, everything was such a
social justice subtly infused, you know, area that we just never even noticed. Everything was
anti-war, everything was vegan. I mean, so early in the 70s. And so I finished elementary,
middle high school. I finished high school in college in Florida, I had my children. And then
I ended up taking my children. I raised my children in Los Angeles and I worked there. I got a
degree in public health. After my children were younger, I went back to school for television.
And I ended up working in Los Angeles for about 13 years. It raised them there. I worked in
the television industry. And then I was actually an empty master. And a dear friend of ours,
Ravelin Gottlieb, my children grew up in Islamic schools. I grew up in Catholic schools. So I
wanted them to do pro-kale schools. So Ravelin Gottlieb used to do these interfaith summer camps
for children. So actually, my kids were like, Mom, you got to get a life. You're by yourself now.
We're out in Korn College. Ravelin said, why don't you come? We're doing this experiment
just outside New York City where we're getting together a bunch of Muslim Jews and Christians.
We're going to run a conference center and we're going to try this interfaith peace building
concept. And so the rest is history. I just packed up and moved out here. And I've just the first
